title: Differences in pollen and macrophytic remains in sediments from various depths in a small kettle-hole lake in southern Finland

Thus four distinct pollen zone boundaries were traced : the rational limit for Picea ( Pc)the decline of QM element ( QM)the rational limit for Secale ( S O -)and the increase of the NAP flora ( especially the anthropogenous element ) .
The NAP increase was contemporaneous with the culmination of Picea .
The horizons of the rational limit for Picea and Secale are shown, as well as the OM decline, as determined by pollen analysis .
The littoral diagrams ( 1-3 ) first represent the Birch-alder-hazel-elm Zone before the increase of Picea .
Concerning the macrofossils from trees, obviously the lake can receive material from an area outside the Kissalammi catchment area .

Picea and Pinus, probably distributed from less than 500 m distance, show relatively the same pattern 410 Mirjami Tolonen BOREAS 13 ( 1984 ) I1 150 K3 50O r - r tF b bl1500 F I nj r200 b E$ dles, leaves, bracts 1-1 fragments Q Fig. 8 .
The pollen diagrams indicate a distinct appearance of Picea seeds and needles beginning at a level corresponding to the invasion of spruce to the area .
The decreases in Picea pollen values, generally found in southern Finnish pollen profiles, have been attributed to forest clearance, and are dated here at A.D. 400 .
Below this stratum, Picea and Secale are found more regularly and more frequently .

The stratigraphy of this sediment, the topmost layer of which has clay-gyttja overlying coarse detritus gyttja and is called a ` field erosion horizonhas been found and described from several small southern Finnish lakes, where permanent settlement and cultivation from prehistoric times has been causing accelerated erosion which has brought material from the watershed area ( e.g. K. Tolonen el al. 1975 ) .

In the area studied, the spruce forest became abundant around 2000-1800 B.C. Huttunen ( 1980 ) reported that according to the corrected tree pollen values in the Lammi area, as much as 80 per cent of the land area was covered by spruce at c. 1700 B.C. From 1300-700 B.Cthe fluctuations shown by the spruce curve coincide with sporadic appearances of pollen types, for example Plantago major, Urtica and Chenopodiaceae ( see also Huttunen 1980:33 ) .
In addition to high Poaceae, Artemisia, Hippophae, Thalictrum and Chenopodiaceae frequency, components such as Rumex, Humulus and Pteridium are found .

A significant change takes place in the pollen composition after the Piceu invasion : first a decline in the Quercetum rnixtum ( QM -)dated here 2 500 B.Pthen the introduction of rye during the first centuries A.D. ( So -)and finally the general increase of NAP flora along with a decline of spruce .

Submerged genera, such as Myriophyllum species, Ceratophyllum demersum and Najas Jexilis, frequently found in abundance in southern Finnish lake sediments and formed during early developmental phases ( e.g. M. Tolonen 1978, 1980 -)seem not to have invaded the basin at all .

Regarding the sporadic accumulation and/or erosion of previously deposited gyttja at site 1, in the topmost 10 cm sequence it appears that no colonization of submersed communities took place in this exposed habitat earlier than during the last decade, when Elodea canadensis spread, succeeded by weakly rooted and pleustophytic plants ( Utricularia vulgaris, Lemna trisulcata ) and aquatic mosses ( Calliergon cordifolium, Drepanocladus spp)-

After 1.600 B.Pthe marked change in lithology is due to a heavy rise in organic and minerogenic input from the unforested watershed .

A significant change takes place in the pollen composition after the Piceu invasion : first a decline in the Quercetum rnixtum ( QM -)dated here 2 500 B.Pthen the introduction of rye during the first centuries A.D. ( So -)and finally the general increase of NAP flora along with a decline of spruce .

A significant change takes place in the pollen composition after the Piceu invasion : first a decline in the Quercetum rnixtum ( QM -)dated here 2 500 B.Pthen the introduction of rye during the first centuries A.D. ( So -)and finally the general increase of NAP flora along with a decline of spruce .
This decline is a consequence of forest clearance after c. 1 600 B.P. .
The decreases in Picea pollen values, generally found in southern Finnish pollen profiles, have been attributed to forest clearance, and are dated here at A.D. 400 .
First, there were temporary fluctuations in the relative frequency, but later, at around A.D. 400, the final decline took place .

Clay gyttja above the 1/11 contact ( layer I ) accumulated in Kissalammi over the last 1 600 years, as concluded from the pollen curves provides an indication of the amount of erosion from the watershed area .
In the upper 10cm sequence of the core taken closest to the shore, a strongly retarded or interrupted deposition over the last 1 000 years is seen .

In the area studied, the spruce forest became abundant around 2000-1800 B.C. Huttunen ( 1980 ) reported that according to the corrected tree pollen values in the Lammi area, as much as 80 per cent of the land area was covered by spruce at c. 1700 B.C. From 1300-700 B.Cthe fluctuations shown by the spruce curve coincide with sporadic appearances of pollen types, for example Plantago major, Urtica and Chenopodiaceae ( see also Huttunen 1980:33 ) .

In the area studied, the spruce forest became abundant around 2000-1800 B.C. Huttunen ( 1980 ) reported that according to the corrected tree pollen values in the Lammi area, as much as 80 per cent of the land area was covered by spruce at c. 1700 B.C. From 1300-700 B.Cthe fluctuations shown by the spruce curve coincide with sporadic appearances of pollen types, for example Plantago major, Urtica and Chenopodiaceae ( see also Huttunen 1980:33 ) .

In the area studied, the spruce forest became abundant around 2000-1800 B.C. Huttunen ( 1980 ) reported that according to the corrected tree pollen values in the Lammi area, as much as 80 per cent of the land area was covered by spruce at c. 1700 B.C. From 1300-700 B.Cthe fluctuations shown by the spruce curve coincide with sporadic appearances of pollen types, for example Plantago major, Urtica and Chenopodiaceae ( see also Huttunen 1980:33 ) .
Traces of continual and more intense forest clearance appear in the pollen profiles at levels dated around the first centuries A.D. .
: Paleohydrological changes in the tempcrate zone in the last 15000 years .

relevant_sentences.text: Differences in pollen and macrophytic remains in sediments from various depths in a small kettle-hole lake in southern Finland MIRJAMI TOLONEN BOW A Tolonen, Mirjami 1984 1201 : Differences in pollen and macrophytic remains in sediments from various depths in a small kettle-hole lake in southern Finland .
Boreas, Val .
but revealed only slight differences in pollen and macrofossil assemblages .
Between 9.000 and 8, ooO B.P. .
organic sediments focused into the central depth of the basin and no sediment accumulated in the littoral sites in water < 7.5 m deep .
From around 5 000 to 4.500 B.Pdeposition took place more or less continuously at all four sites .
After 1.600 B.Pthe marked change in lithology is due to a heavy rise in organic and minerogenic input from the unforested watershed .
The littoral cores show that not only does the water depth cause rcdeposition and focusing of sediment, but also the morphometry of the basin .
Environmental changes and human impact on lake ( see Dearing 1982 ) .
The lake, having no Lake Kissalammi, a small eutrophicated lake, inflowing stream, was very suitable for this have been studied .
Pollen analysis was made us - study, because no potential over-representation ing late-Holocene varved sediments ( M. Tolonen of the regional pollen component is present ( e.g. 1981 ) .
In the north there is an In shallow water sediments, for example, an esker ridge 20 m high .
over-representation of Pinus can be observed ( Lundqvist & Thomasson 1924 ; Lundqvist 1927 ; Hopkins 1950 ; Salmi 1962 ) .

Studies concentrating on these problems include Davis et al. ( 1971 -)Description of the site Berglund ( 1973 -)Pennington ( 1973 -)S ~ n s t e - Lake Kissalammi ( Fig. 1 ) is situated in the Finn - gaard & Mangerud ( 1977 ) .

Kissalammi has a regularly of Finnish basins, have been presented by Al - shaped, steep-sided and circular kettle-hole basin honen ( 1967 -)Huttunen & K. Tolonen ( 1977 -)where the area of the shallow margin is small K. Tolonen et al. ( 1979 -)Huttunen el al. ( 1978 ) compared with the rest of the lake bed area ( Fig .
and K. Tolonen ( 1980 -)among others .
Odkm Fig. 1 .
Location map of Lake Kissalammi .
( 407 400 m3 ) divided by the area gives a mean depth of 8.7 m .
There is no inflowing stream entering the basin, and the effluent flows along a ditch on its eastern part .
Fig. 2 .
Bathymetric map of Lake Kissalammi .

The hydrographic survey was carried out during the winter ice-cover ; the mapping was carried out systematically by measuring the water depths on a 40 x 40 m grid basis ( close to the shore an adequate number of depth points were fixed with a 10 x 10 m grid ) .
Distinct changes in sediment types and colour provided a means of correlating synchronous levels .

For micro and macrofossil records, three nearshore sediment profiles ( Figs. 3 and 4 ) taken with a Russian sampler ( 100 x 10 cm -)at 5.0 ( 32 m BOREAS 13 ( 1984 ) Kettle-hole lake deposits 405 Fig. 3 .
Transect A-A(- Fig. 2 ) of Lake Kissalammi showing presen t bottom surface and organic sediment thickness .
Numbers 1 4 as in Fig. 2 .
The 160 cm long central core, sampled by deep-freezing, comprised only the topmost section .
This section has accumulated during the last c. 5 500 years .
New borings for the lower section of the central profile, down to the silty clay bottom, were made through the ice with a Russian sampler ( 5 X 50 cm ) in March 1983 .
Core correlations for the additional profiles were made by comparing the pollen percentages .

Thus four distinct pollen zone boundaries were traced : the rational limit for Picea ( Pc)the decline of QM element ( QM)the rational limit for Secale ( S O -)and the increase of the NAP flora ( especially the anthropogenous element ) .
The NAP increase was contemporaneous with the culmination of Picea .

Older-than-expected 14Cages have often been obtained for upper sequences of lake sediments which received man-induced allochthonous material from the drainage area ( e.g. Tutin 1969, 1975 ; K. Tolonen 1980 ) .
As will be described later, the sedimentation in Lake Kissalammi was highly influenced by such a source, so new radiocarbon datings were not attempted here .
In the loss-on-ignition analyses, samples were dried overnight at 105 ° C and burned at 550 ° C for four hours .
Laboratory methods for pollen analysis are given in more detail in Tolonen ( 1981 ) .
The results The lithostratigraphy of the cores is as follows ( Fig. 4 -)Main central profile ( 4 : a, b -)a 0-160 cm Varved coarse detritus gyttja .
At c. 95 cm and upwards, clayey and slightly silty .
b 140-180 Varved detritus gyttja, brown to dark brown .
180-190 Fine detritus gyttja ( varveness not examined ) .
The boundaries are diffuse .
tion .
In its lowermost part, representing the basal silt and clay sequence, the central pollen diagram ( profile K4b ) shows the Pine Assemblage Zone ( Regional, Southwestern Finland ; Donner 1971 ) .
This zone has a comparatively high proportion of NAP, here represented by a number of species from the first vegetation cover in the area .
In addition to high Poaceae, Artemisia, Hippophae, Thalictrum and Chenopodiaceae frequency, components such as Rumex, Humulus and Pteridium are found .
These are elements generally found in Early Flandrian sediments in southern Finland ( e.g. K. Tolonen & Ruuhijarvi 1976 ; Donner et al. 1978 ; M. Tolonen 1980 ) .

At the 175 and 180 cm levels, several large Poaceae pollen grains ( 45 pm ) were thought to be spontaneous seashore graminids, cf. Elymus, in accord - Littoral profile ( 1 -)0-10 cm Clay gyttja, grey .
10-60 Compact detritus gyttja, brown, changes downwards to finer grained .
6 @ Silty clay gyttja, with sand .
Upper boundary diffuse .
distance from the bank m Littoral profile ( 2 -)0 - 80 cm Silly clay gyttja, grey .
80-165 Detritus gyttja, brown .
165-170 Compact and very dry fine detritus gyttja, greenish brown .
Downwards becomes silty .
175 - Sandy compact bottom .
5.0 7.5 4 Center 15 ( 141 ) 3 shore south 4.5 Littoral profile ( 3 -)0-120 cm Clay gyttja, grey .
120-190 Detritus gyttja, brown, with abundant re - mains of Bryales peat .
190-198 Fine detritus gyttja, green .
19 % Silty clay, grey, upper boundary diffuse .
Downwards with sandy layers .

The stratigraphy of this sediment, the topmost layer of which has clay-gyttja overlying coarse detritus gyttja and is called a ` field erosion horizonhas been found and described from several small southern Finnish lakes, where permanent settlement and cultivation from prehistoric times has been causing accelerated erosion which has brought material from the watershed area ( e.g. K. Tolonen el al. 1975 ) .
Pollen analysis Only selected curves in the pollen diagrams ( Figs. 6 7 ) are shown .
The principal features described here comprise in the first place such irregularities as hiatuses and variations in deposi - Fig. 4 .
Sediment cores from Lake Kissalammi .
Stratum numbers : I = clayed gyttja, I1 = coarse detritus gyttja, 111 = fine detritus gyttja, IV = clay, V = sand, H = hiatus .
The horizons of the rational limit for Picea and Secale are shown, as well as the OM decline, as determined by pollen analysis .
Ages from varve counts for profile 4 from M. Tolonen ( 1981 ) .
Fig. 5 .
Ash weight ( as percentage dry weight ) for sediment cores from Lake Kissalammi .

The arrows indicate the visual ckdyed gyttjdcoarse detritus gyttja contact ( upper arrow ) ( cf. Fig. 4 ) and the horizon for the permanent settlement horizon with Secale cultivation ( lower arrow -)as determined by pollen analysis .
ance with the diagnostics in Andersen ( 1979 ) .
Upwards the NAP percentage from the total pollen sum falls steeply .
The littoral diagrams ( 1-3 ) first represent the Birch-alder-hazel-elm Zone before the increase of Picea .
This increase ( c. 4200 B.P. ) is very clear in all diagrams .

A significant change takes place in the pollen composition after the Piceu invasion : first a decline in the Quercetum rnixtum ( QM -)dated here 2 500 B.Pthen the introduction of rye during the first centuries A.D. ( So -)and finally the general increase of NAP flora along with a decline of spruce .
This decline is a consequence of forest clearance after c. 1 600 B.P. .
The NAP composition reflects progressive stages in the development of agriculture and the clearing of land .
This is possibly due to a different canopy component ( Tauber 1965 ) caused by a belt of trees around the shore .
Only in the lower part of profile 1 did the Pinus and Alnus curves show minor fluctuations .
The curves in the other part of the profile showed very constant and regular trends, even in the littoral cores ; no major over-representation due to the pollen 's flotation ability was found .
This phenomenon may be explained partly by the fact that there was redeposition of sediment which came from near the shallow western shore after ditch digging in the late 1800s or early 1900s .
Drastic disturbances in a lake basin in eastern Finland as a result of ditching has been described by Vuorinen ( 1977 ) .
Water level decreases affected not only sediment transport, but 14C-ages, too .
The percentage base used was CAP for trees and ZP for others .
Dates inferred from deepwater core K4 .
Plant macrofossils and development of the local vegetation Macrofossil and pollen records in the same cores corroborate and thus conclusions from a more local vegetation can be made .
Fruits and seeds originating from the lake vegetation are found only sparsely in all cores .

The few seeds and fruits from the hy - drop - hy - te lake vegetation found in different layers in pro- file 3 - nymphaeids Nuphar, Nymphuea and Po - tumogeton nutuns - may be interpreted as origi - nating mainly from an area where these plant communities are best developed at present .
He - BOREAS 13 ( 1984 ) K4 a Id 2 v, Jz h a 2 IKettle-hole lake deposits 409 VARIA P 2 4z NLL 2 3yeawrs ISPERGULA 1 .
CENTAUREA I Wz a W 0 3a a mLINUM 500 1000 1500 2000 2500 4000 6000 HUMULUS HI PPOPHAE ARTEMlSlA Wz LL 8000 Fig. 7 .
Simplified relative pollen diagram from profile K4 .
The upper part of the diagram is redrawn from M .

Tolonen ( 1981 -)the lower part is from a new core ( for details see the text ) lophytes show only slight long-term changes, as concluded from the presence of a seed of Hippuris and tissues of Equisetum and Carex .
It is known that no definite conclusion can be drawn on the presence/absence basis of a fossil .
However, it is tempting to propose that areas favourable to elodeids and isoetids did not exist in the lake .

Submerged genera, such as Myriophyllum species, Ceratophyllum demersum and Najas Jexilis, frequently found in abundance in southern Finnish lake sediments and formed during early developmental phases ( e.g. M. Tolonen 1978, 1980 -)seem not to have invaded the basin at all .

Isoetes is often found to become more abundant in sequences approaching the late Holocene, along with the lowering of the water level and/or increased mineral matter content of the sediment ( e.g. Vuorela 1980 ) .

Even though a spreading of the submersed species might have occurred in the uninvestigated parts of the lake, it has to be pointed out that not one single microfossil - pollen, spore or leaf spine - was found in the analysed cores .

Regarding the sporadic accumulation and/or erosion of previously deposited gyttja at site 1, in the topmost 10 cm sequence it appears that no colonization of submersed communities took place in this exposed habitat earlier than during the last decade, when Elodea canadensis spread, succeeded by weakly rooted and pleustophytic plants ( Utricularia vulgaris, Lemna trisulcata ) and aquatic mosses ( Calliergon cordifolium, Drepanocladus spp)-
( M. Tolonen 1981 ) .
Concerning the macrofossils from trees, obviously the lake can receive material from an area outside the Kissalammi catchment area .

Picea and Pinus, probably distributed from less than 500 m distance, show relatively the same pattern 410 Mirjami Tolonen BOREAS 13 ( 1984 ) I1 150 K3 50O r - r tF b bl1500 F I nj r200 b E$ dles, leaves, bracts 1-1 fragments Q Fig. 8 .
Macrofossil diagrams from sediment cores K1, K 2 and K3 .
By comparing the macrofossils and pollen produced by the same vegetation around the lake, good agreement between the relative frequencies can be seen .
The pollen diagrams indicate a distinct appearance of Picea seeds and needles beginning at a level corresponding to the invasion of spruce to the area .
The result may be taken as an indication of a location rather close to the lake .
Thus, as the distance from the macrofossil origin increases, the number of macrofossils decreases .
The decreases in Picea pollen values, generally found in southern Finnish pollen profiles, have been attributed to forest clearance, and are dated here at A.D. 400 .

Some stands of Alnus, Populus, Salk and Jun - BOREAS 13 ( 1984 ) Kettle-hole lake deposits 411 iperus with Betula have probably existed among the local shore vegetation, though a part of Betula fruits might originate from outside the catchment area .

From the actual gramineous or herbaceous helophytes from near the shore, nothing can be concluded from the presence of macrofossils, while the few remains of Linum, Rumex, Urtica and Chenopodium at K3 point to cultivated habitats .
Discussion The core of the deep covers the whole Flandrian sequence, from the isolation of the basin ( Pine NAP P.A.Z. ) to the present .

The three shallowwater diagrams cover the Subboreal Chronozone period ( Mangerud et al. 1974 -)and represent the later part of the Birch-alder-hazel-elm zone and the spruce-pine zone ( regional P.A.Z. ) .
From the Preboreal Boreal Chronozone to the early Atlantic Chronozone, there is a successive change from silty clay ( layer IV ) to gyttja ( 111 and 11 ) .
This change reflects the natural development .
The nature of the transition was determined using the pollen diagram .
These interruptions have not been referred to here as hiatuses .

Clay gyttja above the 1/11 contact ( layer I ) accumulated in Kissalammi over the last 1 600 years, as concluded from the pollen curves provides an indication of the amount of erosion from the watershed area .
Thus, the ash-weight of sediment gives estimates of ` sediment yield ' from the surroundings ( the likely increase in production of biogenic silica was included in the figures ) .

After agricultural activity was started around the lake and after the soaking of fibre plants started in the lake, the remains of phytoplankton identified in the sediment clearly show eutrophication ( unpublished data ) .
Indications of erosion, redeposition and focusing of sediment were found in Kissalammi .
In the upper 10cm sequence of the core taken closest to the shore, a strongly retarded or interrupted deposition over the last 1 000 years is seen .
Below this stratum, Picea and Secale are found more regularly and more frequently .
This is characteristic of the early Subatlantic Chronozone .
Since no major disturbances have occurred in the deep central part of the lake, rhythmically laminated sediments have formed ( M. Tolonen 1981 ) .
Davis et al. ( 1971 ) found that high ratios of herbaceous plant pollen to tree pollen can occur in littoral sediment and low ratios in deep water sediment .
A somewhat similar distribution was found in Norway by Sejnstegaard & Mangerud ( 1977 ) .

None of the diagrams shows any noteworthy over-representation of coniferous pollen, which is known to be common in shallow water sediments ( e.g. Lundqvist 1927 ; Digerfeldt 1973 -)though there are studies which show no indication of pollen enrichment in the nearshore sites ( Pennington 1947 ; Digerfeldt 1972 ; Berglund 1973 ) .

In the area studied, the spruce forest became abundant around 2000-1800 B.C. Huttunen ( 1980 ) reported that according to the corrected tree pollen values in the Lammi area, as much as 80 per cent of the land area was covered by spruce at c. 1700 B.C. From 1300-700 B.Cthe fluctuations shown by the spruce curve coincide with sporadic appearances of pollen types, for example Plantago major, Urtica and Chenopodiaceae ( see also Huttunen 1980:33 ) .
An absence of cereal pollen in K1, K2 and K3 points out the weakness of this method for discovering smallscale or short-term cultivations by a ` routine ' pollen count .
Sampled at intervals of 5 cm, the cores give a resolution of about every 100-200 years at each level .
Traces of continual and more intense forest clearance appear in the pollen profiles at levels dated around the first centuries A.D. .
A continual influence of human activity points to permanent settlement, including cultivation of Secale on the reference area .
All this is also traceable b y, 412 Mirjami Tolonen BOREAS 13 ( 1984 -)routine ' analysis .
The long-term decline of spruce started at the onset of rye cultivation .
First, there were temporary fluctuations in the relative frequency, but later, at around A.D. 400, the final decline took place .
There was a high expansion of the NAP element during this final decline .
In this lake, sediment focusing was observed to be greatest in the shallowest site studied, i.e. on the less exposed, but steeper bank .
I am grateful to the Research Council for the Natural Sciences at the Academy of Finland for financial support .
